title: Question 32

children: A 45-year-old woman is evaluated for increasing shortness of breath and fatigue for the past 6 weeks and weight loss of 4.5 kg (10 lb) over the past 2 months. She has no other symptoms. She has a history of rheumatoid arthritis. Her only medications are methotrexate and folic acid.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Typical chronic changes of rheumatoid arthritis are present in her hands, wrists, and feet in the absence of active synovitis. Chest findings are consistent with bilateral pleural effusions.
Chest radiograph demonstrates bilateral pleural effusions and bulky mediastinal lymphadenopathy. Thoracentesis is performed, and 1100 mL of milky fluid is drained.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A chylothorax is diagnosed by a triglyceride level greater than 110 mg/dL (1.24 mmol/L), and it is typically a lymphocytic predominant exudative effusion.
The most common nontraumatic cause of chylothorax is malignancy, of which lymphoma is the most common.
The most likely diagnosis is chylothorax (

). Chylothorax refers to the presence of chyle within the pleural space. Chylothorax has both traumatic and nontraumatic causes. The most common traumatic cause is thoracic surgery. Esophagostomy carries the highest risk followed by mediastinal lymph node dissection, mediastinal tumor resection, and any surgery involving the lower neck and mediastinum. The most common nontraumatic cause is malignancy, of which lymphoma is the most common. Other possible nontraumatic causes include lymphatic disorders and chylous ascites. In patients with nontraumatic cases, the mechanism of the chylothorax varies with the underlying cause. In this patient it is most likely secondary to compressive obstruction due to bulky lymphadenopathy. Chest pain and fever are rare in patients with chylothorax, but the presence of fever may represent an underlying lymphoma. Chylous effusions have a high protein concentration making them exudates by Light's criteria. The explanation for elevated protein in a chylous effusion is unknown. The pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is typically low, reflective of a transudate. If elevated, it often reflects the underlying cause of the effusion, such as a malignancy. A chylothorax is diagnosed by a triglyceride level greater than 110 mg/dL (1.24 mmol/L), and it is typically a lymphocytic predominant effusion. Although chylothorax is often milky in appearance, as is a cholesterol effusion, it can appear serous or sanguineous.

) is diagnosed by a pleural fluid cholesterol level greater than 200 mg/dL (5.18 mmol/L). Cholesterol effusions are quite rare and when present are most commonly associated with tuberculosis, rheumatoid effusions, and other chronic pleural effusions.

) is incorrect as the patient has no clinical features of infection (fever, chest pain, leukocytosis). In addition, empyema is not milky in appearance and is typically associated with a low pleural fluid pH and low glucose.
) is typically an inflammatory effusion with a low pH (<7.2), a low glucose level (<40 mg/dL [2.2 mmol/L]), and an elevated LDH level.

references: Feller-Kopman D, Light R. Pleural disease. N Engl J Med. 2018;378:740-751.
